text: reclaimed land the tallest building on
earth and the busiest airport in the
world Dubai is rarely noted for its eco
credentials but could that be about to
change with this the Emirates new mosque
was funded by a private donation and can
house up to three thousand five hundred
worshippers it's the first ever built to
meet the US Green Building Council's
guidelines the carpet used here are
selected by the green building
requirements it's a low V OC type low
emitting a smell type we have here the
Pump Room resident engineer Ahmed Arwen
Hassoun took us on an eco tour treated
water is used for the irrigation system
for the irrigation water for the
landscaping system the consultants
behind this mosque say they've cut down
the water needed by 50% and energy by
25% after the city's endowment committee
insisted on a green element to a swage
climate fears I think what we have been
doing for the past hundred years
eventually we have eroded our climate so
it wasn't like this 100 years ago it's
it all comes back to us and what we have
done to get where we are and from this
point onward what we can do to stop it
reduce it or minimize it
the choice of a mosque to promote
environmental consciousness is
particularly pertinent in this part of
the world where religion is embedded in
people's lives the success of this
mosque is being keenly watched not least
in neighboring Saudi Arabia that country
has already sent a team of engineers
here to see how it's done so is this a
more environmentally friendly do by
responding to climate change this is the
first time in the history of the Middle
East that the word of sustainability is
spread through a mosque and it is very
likely that it will reach the grassroots
Dubai's population is expected to rise
5% this year which means more carbon
dioxide emitting buildings the Eco
message will need to spread fast
mark labelled BBC News Dubai
